notes.text:
An update for kernel-rt is now available for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 9.2 Extended Update Support.

Red Hat Product Security has rated this update as having a security impact of Moderate. A Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) base score, which gives a detailed severity rating, is available for each vulnerability from the CVE link(s) in the References section.
notes.title: Topic

notes.text:
The kernel-rt packages provide the Real Time Linux Kernel, which enables fine-tuning for systems with extremely high determinism requirements.

Security Fix(es):

* kernel: untrusted VMM can trigger int80 syscall handling (CVE-2024-25744)

* kernel: netfilter: nftables: exthdr: fix 4-byte stack OOB write (CVE-2023-52628)

Bug Fix(es):

* kernel-rt: kernel: untrusted VMM can trigger int80 syscall handling (JIRA:RHEL-30421)

* kernel-rt: kernel: netfilter: nftables: exthdr: fix 4-byte stack OOB write (JIRA:RHEL-31093)

* kernel-rt: update RT source tree to the latest RHEL-9.2 ad hoc schedule build (JIRA:RHEL-34746)
notes.title: Details

notes.text: An out-of-bounds write flaw was found in the Linux kernelâs Netfilter functionality. This flaw allows a local user to crash or potentially escalate their privileges on the system.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: kernel: netfilter: nftables: exthdr: fix 4-byte stack OOB write
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: This issue is fixed in Red Hat Enterprise Linux 9.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

The system must be rebooted for this update to take effect.

In order to trigger the issue, it requires the ability to create user/net namespaces.

On non-containerized deployments of Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8, you can disable user namespaces by setting user.max_user_namespaces to 0:

# echo "user.max_user_namespaces=0" > /etc/sysctl.d/userns.conf
# sysctl -p /etc/sysctl.d/userns.conf

On containerized deployments, such as Red Hat OpenShift Container Platform, do not use this mitigation as the functionality is needed to be enabled.

vulnerabilities.title: kernel: netfilter: nftables: exthdr: fix 4-byte stack OOB write

notes.text: A flaw was found in the Linux kernel. A VMM can inject external interrupts on any arbitrary vector at any time, which may allow the guest OS to be manipulated from the VMM side.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: kernel: untrusted VMM can trigger int80 syscall handling
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

The system must be rebooted for this update to take effect.
This vulnerability can be mitigated by disabling 32-bit emulation by default for TDX and SEV. The user can override it with the ia32_emulation=y command line option.

vulnerabilities.title: kernel: untrusted VMM can trigger int80 syscall handling
